The Vicksburg Campaign Trail Battlefields Preservation Act of 1999 aims to preserve key Civil War battlefields along the Vicksburg Campaign Trail in Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Tennessee. This includes conducting a feasibility study to determine preservation measures for these historically significant sites. The Vicksburg Campaign Trail Battlefields Preservation Act of 1999 aims to preserve key Civil War battlefields along the Vicksburg Campaign Trail in Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Tennessee by conducting a feasibility study to determine preservation measures for historically significant sites. SEC. 103. DEFINITIONS. The term "Campaign Trail State" refers to Mississippi, Louisiana, Arkansas, and Tennessee. "Civil War battlefields" include sites like Helena and Arkansas Post in Arkansas, Goodrich's Landing near Transylvania, and locations around Lake Providence. The Campaign Trail State includes Civil War battlefields such as Milliken's Bend, Winter Quarters in Tensas Parish, Grant's landing site at Bruinsburg, and the battlefield at Port Gibson. The Campaign Trail State in Mississippi features various Civil War battlefields, including Shaifer House, Bethel Church, the ruins of Windsor, Grand Gulf, Raymond, Jackson, Champion Hill, and Big Black River. The Campaign Trail State in Mississippi includes key Civil War battlefields such as Big Black River Bridge, Haynes Bluff, Chickasaw Bayou, Pemberton's Headquarters, and Confederate fortifications near Grenada. The Vicksburg Campaign Trail National Battlefields include key Civil War sites like Greirson's Raid start, LaGrange, Tennessee, and other sites chosen by the Secretary. The map for this trail is specified by the Secretary of the Interior through the National Park Service Director. The feasibility study for the Vicksburg Campaign Trail National Battlefields is specified by the Secretary of the Interior through the National Park Service Director. The Secretary of the Interior, through the National Park Service Director, will conduct a feasibility study within a year to determine measures for preserving Civil War battlefields. This study will involve using advanced technology to identify significant properties and evaluate options for managing the battlefields. The National Park Service Director administers and manages Civil War battlefields, has legal authority to receive and disburse funds, enter agreements, and acquire land for preservation. The National Park Service Director has the authority to acquire land for preservation through various means such as gift, purchase, or donation. Recommendations are made for the management and preservation of Civil War battlefields, including forming partnerships with different entities and ensuring local involvement in their development. The Secretary will submit a report on the findings of a study on Civil War battlefields to the Senate and House committees. $1,500,000 is authorized for this purpose. TITLE II--MISSISSIPPI CIVIL RIGHTS TRAIL STUDY

SEC. 201. SHORT TITLE.

This title is known as the "Mississippi Civil Rights Trail Study Act of 1999".

SEC. 202. AUTHORIZATION OF STUDY. The Secretary of the Interior must complete a study within a year to identify significant civil rights movement sites in Mississippi for historical interpretation. The study will evaluate the feasibility of establishing a Civil Rights Trail by linking these sites. The study will use criteria similar to those for potential inclusion in the National Park System. The study will focus on significant civil rights movement sites in Mississippi, particularly in the counties of Hindes, Lauderdale, Neshoba, Amite, Adams, Harrison, Jackson, Marshall, Lafayette, Clay, Lowndess, and Noxubee. The Secretary will submit a report to the Senate and House committees on the findings of the study within 60 days. $2,000,000 is authorized for this title.
